fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''Fort Valley''' is a [[mountain]] [[valley]] in [[Shenandoah County, Virginia
column5: December 12, 2016}}</ref>  It is often called \"valley within a valley\" as it lies between the two arms of the northern [[Massanutten Mountain]] range in the [[Shenandoah Valley]], which are part of the  in the [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]].  The eastern ridgeline of Fort Valley is named Massanutten Mountain and is basically continuous for the eastern length of Fort Valley.  The western ridgeline of the valley, also part of the Massanutten range, is composed of three named mountains, from north to south: Three Top Mountain, Powell Mountain and Short Mountain. Additionally, behind Three Top and Powell mountains another ridgeline in the chain is called Green Mountain, which has a smaller highland valley called Little Fort Valley between it and the western ridgelines. In addition, there are several other named smaller mountains and promontories within Fort Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is almost entirely enclosed. At its southern end it is enclosed with an access point called Moreland Gap, and to the north it is constricted and nearly closed but for where [[Passage Creek]] flows through a narrow gap providing passage towards Front Royal. Passage Creek also is a prominent element of Fort Valley, running the entire length of the entire valley at its center, starting in Crishman Hollow in the mountains in the south and flowing north, aided by other streams and runs, until it exits Fort Valley just past Elizabeth Furnace. The valley opens out toward the center, becoming about {{convert
column4: spell=in}} wide at its widest. The extreme southern end of the valley, the highlands of Crishman Hollow, is in Page County. The remainder of Fort Valley is in Shenandoah County, with the border of Shenandoah and Page counties being along the eastern ridgeline of Masanutten Mountain.  In all, Fort Valley is {{convert

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is entirely rural, consisting mostly of private farmland, surrounded by the [[George Washington National Forest]] (GWNF), which covers the slopes and ridges on both the east and west mountains. The [[Elizabeth Furnace]] and [[Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area]] of the GWNF are located within Fort Valley.

Between Three Top, Powell and Green Mountain there are two gaps, Mine Gap and Woodstock Gap, the latter of which features a dirt road, Rt 758, from the town of  Woodstock to the Woodstock Tower, which sits on the ridge of Powell Mountain offering panoramic views of the town and the Shenandoah Valley. Woodstock Tower is a historic observation post built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1935.

Between Powell and Short mountains is Edinburg Gap, a more frequently traveled paved road that offers primary access from the west into Fort Valley. At the top of Edinburg Gap on the southern side there is an extensive all terrain vehicle (ATV) trail system set up by the Forest Service. On the northern side of the gap starts Peter's Mill Road, an off-highway vehicle (OHV) road made available for jeeps and four wheel drive vehicles. Peter's Mill Road runs from Edinburg Gap to Woodstock Gap along the higher reaches of the Little Fort Valley. In the east, Fort Valley is accessed via a paved road through Edith Gap that also serves as entrance to Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area. There are no roads accessing Fort Valley on the east, over Massanutten Mountain, from Camp Roosevelt to Elizabeth furnace at the northern apex of the valley.
Roads exit the valley at its northern end ([[Virginia State Route 678
column4: Front Royal]], at Edinburg Gap ([[Virginia State Route 675
column8: New Market]], and Edith Gap (S.R. 675) towards [[Luray, Virginia
column9: Luray]]. There is also the dirt road that leads to [[Woodstock, Virginia

British businessman}}: Tuscarora trail]], a 252-mile long distance hiking trail that passes through Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, proceeds along the northeast ridgeline of Fort Valley, entering from just above Shenandoah State Park on the eastern ridgeline of Massanutten Mountain. The hiking trail passes through the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area, ascends Green Mountain and exits on Doll's Ridge on the western slope of Three Top Mountain as it descends towards the [[Tom's Brook Battlefield]] in the Shenandoah Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: The [[Massanutten Trail]] circumnavigates the entire ridgeline of the Fort Valley, 71 miles in total. It was built by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC), completed in 2001. Prior to 2001, different portions of the trail had been known by different names and blazed in different colors. With the completion of the missing links, the Forest Service renamed the combined trails as the Massanutten Trail and provided orange blazes along the trail's entire length around Fort Valley.

Fort Valley features two developed U.S. Forest Service recreation areas, [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73687 Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area] toward the northern apex of the Valley, and [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73633 Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area] at Edith Gap in the southeast end of the valley. Both recreation areas were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s. Camp Roosevelt features a hang gliding site nearby, a pavilion, camp sites and access to the Masanutten Trail.  Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area features a pavilion and multiple camping areas, interpretive trails related the historical iron industry at the site, and acess to the Masanutten and Tuscarora trails which share a length of trail leading to Elizabeth Furnace from the east and separate at Elizabeth Furnace north (Massanutten Trail) and west (Tuscarora Trail.)

According to tradition, [[Daniel Morgan]] built the first road into Fort Valley from the north, at the order of [[George Washington]], with a view to holing up in this naturally fortified valley as a possible last stand against the [[British Army
British businessman}}: British]] during the [[American Revolution]]. The [[Continental Army]]'s victory at [[Siege of Yorktown

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[Elizabeth Furnace]] was a blast furnace in the Shenandoah Valley that created pig iron from 1836 – 1888, using Passage Creek for water power. Iron ore was mined in the mountains, purified in the furnace, then pig iron was transported transported over Massanutten Mountain to the South Fork of the Shenandoah River, where it was transported for forging in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The road used to transport the iron is in use today as a hiking trail. At one time, Elizabeth Furnace supported a community associated with the local iron industry. Elizabeth Furnace was destroyed by Union troops in 1864 during operations associated with the [[Battle of Cedar Creek]]. The furnace reopened in 1883 but lacked sufficient output and was abandoned in 1888. The Elizabeth Furnace Cabin is one of the few wooden buildings remaining from the early 1800s when Elizabeth Furnace was active. <ref>https://shenandoahcountyva.us/tourism/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2014/01/Elizabeth_Furnace_rec_Area_info_booklet-sm-res1.pdf</ref>. In 1936 the Civilian Conservation Corps constructed the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area on the site.

Signal Knob, a 2,111 foot barren promontory at the extreme northern ridgeline of Fort Valley that offers sweeping and unobstructed panoramic views of of the Shenandoah Valley northeast and west, was utilized during a Civil War as a strategic military observation post. The observation post can view the nearby Shenandoah Valley battlefields of Cedar Creek, [[Fisher's Hill]] and Tom's Brook. It's accessed by an 11.5 mile round-trip hike from Elizabeth Furnace.
The [[Daniel Munch House]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2002.<ref name=\"nris\">{{NRISref

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''Fort Valley''' is a [[mountain]] [[valley]] in [[Shenandoah County, Virginia
column5: December 12, 2016}}</ref>  It is often called \"valley within a valley\" as it lies between the two arms of the northern [[Massanutten Mountain]] range in the [[Shenandoah Valley]], which are part of the  in the [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]].  The eastern ridgeline of Fort Valley is named Massanutten Mountain and is basically continuous for the eastern length of Fort Valley.  The western ridgeline of the valley, also part of the Massanutten range, is composed of three named mountains, from north to south: Three Top Mountain, Powell Mountain and Short Mountain. Additionally, behind Three Top and Powell mountains another ridgeline in the chain is called Green Mountain, which has a smaller valley called Little Fort Valley between it and the western ridgelines. In addition, there are several other named smaller mountains and promontories within Forth Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is almost entirely enclosed. At its southern end it is enclosed with an access point called Moreland Gap, and to the north it is constricted and nearly closed but for where [[Passage Creek]] flows through a narrow gap providing passage towards Front Royal. Passage Creek also is a prominent element of Fort Valley, running the entire length of the entire valley at its center, starting in Crishman Hollow in the mountains in the south and flowing north, aided by other streams and runs, until it exits Fort Valley just past Elizabeth Furnace. The valley opens out toward the center, becoming about {{convert
column4: spell=in}} wide at its widest. The extreme southern end of the valley, the highlands of Crishman Hollow, is in Page County. The remainder of Fort Valley is in Shenandoah County, with the border of Shenandoah and Page counties being along the eastern ridgeline of Masanutten Mountain.  In all, Fort Valley is {{convert

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is entirely rural, consisting mostly of private farmland, surrounded by the [[George Washington National Forest]] (GWNF), which covers the slopes and ridges on both the east and west mountains. The [[Elizabeth Furnace]] and [[Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area]] of the GWNF are located within Fort Valley.

Between Three Top, Powell and Green Mountain there are two gaps, Mine Gap and Woodstock Gap, the latter of which features a dirt road, Rt 758, from the town of  Woodstock to the Woodstock Tower, which sits on the ridge of Powell Mountain offering panoramic views of the town and the Shenandoah Valley. Woodstock Tower is a historic observation post built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1935.

Between Powell and Short mountains is Edinburg Gap, a more frequently traveled paved road that offers primary access from the west into Fort Valley. At the top of Edinburg Gap on the southern side there is an extensive all terrain vehicle (ATV) trail system set up by the Forest Service. On the northern side of the gap starts Peter's Mill Road, an off-highway vehicle (OHV) road made available for jeeps and four wheel drive vehicles. Peter's Mill Road runs from Edinburg Gap to Woodstock Gap along the higher reaches of the Little Fort Valley. In the east, Fort Valley is accessed via a paved road through Edith Gap that also serves as entrance to Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area. There are no roads accessing Fort Valley on the east, over Massanutten Mountain, from Camp Roosevelt to Elizabeth furnace at the northern apex of the valley.
Roads exit the valley at its northern end ([[Virginia State Route 678
column4: Front Royal]], at Edinburg Gap ([[Virginia State Route 675
column8: New Market]], and Edith Gap (S.R. 675) towards [[Luray, Virginia
column9: Luray]]. There is also the dirt road that leads to [[Woodstock, Virginia

British businessman}}: Tuscarora trail]], a 252-mile long distance hiking trail that passes through Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, proceeds along the northeast ridgeline of Fort Valley, entering from just above Shenandoah State Park on the eastern ridgeline of Massanutten Mountain. The hiking trail passes through the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area, ascends Green Mountain and exits on Doll's Ridge on the western slope of Three Top Mountain as it descends towards the [[Tom's Brook Battlefield]] in the Shenandoah Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: The [[Massanutten Trail]] circumnavigates the entire ridgeline of the Fort Valley, 71 miles in total. It was built by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC), completed in 2001. Prior to 2001, different portions of the trail had been known by different names and blazed in different colors. With the completion of the missing links, the Forest Service renamed the combined trails as the Massanutten Trail and provided orange blazes along the trail's entire length around Fort Valley.

Fort Valley features two developed U.S. Forest Service recreation areas, [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73687 Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area] toward the northern apex of the Valley, and [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73633 Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area] at Edith Gap in the southeast end of the valley. Both recreation areas were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s. Camp Roosevelt features a hang gliding site nearby, a pavilion, camp sites and access to the Masanutten Trail.  Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area features a pavilion and multiple camping areas, interpretive trails related the historical iron industry at the site, and acess to the Masanutten and Tuscarora trails which share a length of trail leading to Elizabeth Furnace from the east and separate at Elizabeth Furnace north (Massanutten Trail) and west (Tuscarora Trail.)

According to tradition, [[Daniel Morgan]] built the first road into Fort Valley from the north, at the order of [[George Washington]], with a view to holing up in this naturally fortified valley as a possible last stand against the [[British Army
British businessman}}: British]] during the [[American Revolution]]. The [[Continental Army]]'s victory at [[Siege of Yorktown

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[Elizabeth Furnace]] was a blast furnace in the Shenandoah Valley that created pig iron from 1836 – 1888, using Passage Creek for water power. Iron ore was mined in the mountains, purified in the furnace, then pig iron was transported transported over Massanutten Mountain to the South Fork of the Shenandoah River, where it was transported for forging in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The road used to transport the iron is in use today as a hiking trail. At one time, Elizabeth Furnace supported a community associated with the local iron industry. Elizabeth Furnace was destroyed by Union troops in 1864 during operations associated with the [[Battle of Cedar Creek]]. The furnace reopened in 1883 but lacked sufficient output and was abandoned in 1888. The Elizabeth Furnace Cabin is one of the few wooden buildings remaining from the early 1800s when Elizabeth Furnace was active. <ref>https://shenandoahcountyva.us/tourism/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2014/01/Elizabeth_Furnace_rec_Area_info_booklet-sm-res1.pdf</ref>. In 1936 the Civilian Conservation Corps constructed the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area on the site.

Signal Knob, a 2,111 foot barren promontory at the extreme northern ridgeline of Fort Valley that offers sweeping and unobstructed panoramic views of of the Shenandoah Valley northeast and west, was utilized during a Civil War as a strategic military observation post. The observation post can view the nearby Shenandoah Valley battlefields of Cedar Creek, [[Fisher's Hill]] and Tom's Brook. It's accessed by an 11.5 mile round-trip hike from Elizabeth Furnace.
The [[Daniel Munch House]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2002.<ref name=\"nris\">{{NRISref

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''''Lady in Cement''''' is a 1968 [[Cinema of the United States
column3: Silver, Alain]]; Ward, Elizabeth; eds. (1992). ''Film Noir: An Encyclopedic Reference to the American Style'' (3rd ed.). Woodstock, New York: [[The Overlook Press]]. {{ISBN
column5: Gordon Douglas]] and starring [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Raquel Welch]], [[Dan Blocker]], [[Martin Gabel]] and [[Richard Conte]].

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: A sequel to the 1967 film ''[[Tony Rome]]'', and based on the novel by [[Marvin H. Albert]], ''Lady in Cement'' was released on November 20, 1968.
While diving off the Miami coast seeking one of the eleven fabled Spanish Galleons sunk in 1591, private investigator Tony Rome ([[Frank Sinatra]]) discovers a dead woman, her [[Cement shoes
British businessman}}: feet encased in cement]], at the bottom of the ocean.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Rome reports this to Lieutenant Dave Santini ([[Richard Conte]]) and thinks nothing more of the incident, until Waldo Gronski ([[Dan Blocker]]) hires him to find a missing woman, Sandra Lomax. Gronski has little in the way of affluence, so he allows Rome to pawn his watch to retain his services.

After investigating the local hotspots and picking up on a few names, Rome soon comes across Kit Forrester ([[Raquel Welch]]), whose party Sandra Lomax was supposed to have attended. Rome's talking to Forrester raises the ire of racketeer Al Mungar ([[Martin Gabel]]), a supposedly reformed gangster who looks after Kit's interests.

Thinking there may be a connection between Lomax, Forrester and Mungar, Rome starts probing into their backgrounds and begins a romantic relationship with Kit. With both cops and crooks chasing him and the omnipresent Gronski breathing down his neck, Rome finds himself deep in a case which provides few answers.
[[File:Raquel Welch Frank Sinatra Lady in Cement.jpg
* [[Steve Peck]] as Paul Mungar (as Steven Peck)
* [[Tommy Uhlar]] as The Kid, Tighe Santini

The film was based on a novel published in 1961 which the ''New York Times'' called \"ingenuous\".<ref>By, A. B. (1961, Jun 04). Criminals at large. New York Times (1923-Current File) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/115449613</ref>

Following the success of ''[[Tony Rome]]'', Aaron Rosenberg hired Marvin Albert to adapt ''Cement'' for Sinatra. The actor made it after ''The Detective''.<ref>Martin, B. (1967, Jun 05). 'Caper' for faye dunaway. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/155789349</ref> Raquel Welch's casting was announced in June 1967.<ref>Dorothy Manners:. (1967, Jun 30). Raquel welch to costar with sinatra. The Washington Post, Times Herald (1959-1973) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/143211118</ref>

[[Sammy Davis Jr]] was to have appeared in the film as the charter boat captain.<ref>Sammy davis to costar with sinatra. (1968, Jan 06). The Washington Post, Times Herald (1959-1973) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/143516569</ref> However Sinatra fell ill and filming was postponed for four weeks. Davis was replaced by Pat Henry in the final film. <ref>Harford, M. (1968, Mar 06). 'SWEET CHARITY' ROLE. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/155915617</ref>

[[Dan Blocker]] was given time away from ''Bonanza'' to play his part. The movie gave an early role to [[Lainie Kazan]].<ref>Rose, B. (1968, Jun 08). Miss kazan weighs love-career choice. Los Angeles Times (1923-Current File) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/155947940</ref>

Welch later said she did not realise her character was an alcoholic until after filming wrapped. \"I'm watching this movie and I'm thinking, 'What the hell has she got on?' At one point, I had this epiphany: 'Oh, she's an alcoholic!' I didn't know that. How could I miss that?... I think I was just so enamoured with Frank Sinatra, you know. He's hypnotic.\"<ref>Wenn. (2017, April 10). Raquel Welch: 'I was awful in Sinatra film' Retrieved April 15, 2017, from [http://www.tv3.ie/xpose/article/entertainment-news/236582/Raquel-Welch-I-was-awful-in-Sinatra-film/ XPOSÉ.ie.]</ref>

Filming started in March 1968. Before and during filming, Sinatra would perform at the Fontainebleau in Miami over a six-week period. Welch would go to watch him and found the experience so inspiring she determined to continue to perform to live audiences in her career.<ref>By, G. C. (1982, May 30). Raquel welch: 'I like a character with backbone'. New York Times (1923-Current File) Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/121982606</ref>
According to Fox records the film required $7,150,000 in rentals to break even and by 11 December 1970 had made $6,825,000 so made a loss to the studio.<ref>{{cite book
column3: title=The Fox that got away : the last days of the Zanuck dynasty at Twentieth Century-Fox

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Opening to mixed reviews, ''Lady in Cement'' is generally considered to be a middling sequel to ''Tony Rome''. Critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film two stars, but singled out Sinatra fopr praise in an otherwise poor review, commenting: “In the movie's few good scenes, Sinatra once again painfully reminds us what a controlled, effective actor he is.” [[Variety (magazine)
British businessman}}: Variety]] noted that “Dan Blocker is excellent as a sympathetic heavy,” whilst John Maloney liked the “fresher script” and “sharp direction.”

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: ''Lady on Cement'' was released on DVD on May 24, 2005 as part of a boxed set along with ''[[Tony Rome]]'' and ''[[The Detective (1968 film)
British businessman}}: The Detective]]'', both also directed by Douglas. No bonus features were included.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''''Me, Myself & I''''' is the seventh [[studio album]] by American rapper [[Fat Joe]]. The album was released on November 14, 2006, by [[Terror Squad (record label)
column4: Imperial]]. The album was supported by the single \"[[Make It Rain]]\" featuring [[Lil Wayne]], which peaked at number 13 on the [[Billboard Hot 100
column5: ''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. The album debuted at number 14 on the [[Billboard Top 200]] and has since sold a total of 206,000 copies.<ref>{{cite magazine
column7: title=Fat Joe Makes 'Room' For New Album
column12: accessdate=November 18, 2009}}</ref> It sold 60,000 copies the first week of release<ref name=\"unkut.com\">{{cite web
column14: title=Ten Fat Joe songs you may have missed

column8: title=Me, Myself and I - Fat Joe

column6: title=Fat Joe :: Me, Myself & I :: Terror Squad Entertainment

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: ''Me, Myself & I'' received mixed reviews from [[Music journalism
British businessman}}: music critics]] who found it to be of less quality compared to ''[[All or Nothing (Fat Joe album)
column3: All or Nothing]]''. [[AllMusic]]'s David Jeffries praised the album for toning down on featured artists to focus more on Joe's deep street lyricism backed by ear-grabbing production, concluding that \"hearing this high-profile thug so boldly reclaiming his street cred without any concessions is exciting and makes it easy to shrug off this driven full-length's one-track mind.\"<ref name=\"AM\"/> Soren Baker of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' praised the album for balancing out the street bangers with contemplative tracks like \"Bendicion Mami\" and \"Story to Tell\", saying that it makes \"Joe's latest a well-rounded affair.\"<ref name=\"LATimes\"/> Andrew Kameka of ''[[HipHopDX]]'' found some of the lyrical content wearing thin but praised Joe for sticking with his gut of performing gruff street tracks with aggressive production, saying that \"Fat Joe doesn't hold his weight on a few of the album's songs, but he delivers enough strength to silence anyone who questions his place in Hip Hop.<ref name=\"HHDX\"/>

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Steve 'Flash' Juon of ''RapReviews'' found the lyrical content to be samey because of Joe's lack of energy and that they were more suited for [[Rick Ross]] and [[Pitbull (rapper)
British businessman}}: Pitbull]], concluding with, \"That personality is completely absent from ''Me, Myself & I'', which may make this the most ironically titled album of his career.\"<ref name=\"RR\"/> [[Jody Rosen]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' said that despite two Lil Wayne collaborations, the album suffers from generic brag raps and southern production that are more slave to trends than imaginative, concluding with, \"If only Joe’s CD had less of he, himself, and him.\"<ref name=\"EW\"/> Evan McGarvey of [[Stylus Magazine]] criticized the album for showcasing Joe's worst tendencies of borrowing regional hip hop beats and delivering sex and street lyrics that sound more humorous, concluding with \"Don’t buy it. He’ll be back next year saying the same thing, synth-de-jour in tow.\"<ref name=\"Stylus\"/>

column3: 绞股蓝}}}}, [[Pinyin]]: jiǎogǔlán, literally \"twisting blue plant\"), is a [[dioecious]], [[herbaceous]] climbing [[vine]] of the family [[Cucurbitaceae]] ([[cucumber]] or [[gourd]] family) widely distributed in South and East Asia as well as New Guinea. Jiaogulan has recently been incorporated into [[traditional medicine]], although there is no [[evidence-based medicine]] that demonstrates any effects on human health.<ref name=\"drugs\">{{cite web

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Among many common names are five-leaf ginseng, poor man's ginseng, miracle grass, fairy herb, sweet tea vine, gospel herb, and southern ginseng.<ref name=drugs/>
Jiaogulan belongs to the genus ''[[Gynostemma]]'', in the family [[Cucurbitaceae]], which includes [[cucumber]]s, [[gourd]]s, and [[melon]]s.<ref name=\"FoC-genus\">{{cite web
column8: publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis, MO & Harvard University Herbaria, Cambridge, MA
column16: publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis, MO & Harvard University Herbaria, Cambridge, MA
column17: accessdate=2 May 2018}}</ref> Its fruit is a small purple inedible gourd. It is a climbing vine, attaching itself to supports using [[tendril]]s. The serrated leaflets commonly grow in groups of five (as in ''G. pentaphyllum'') although some species can have groups of three or seven leaflets. The plant is [[dioecious]], meaning each plant exists either as male or female. Therefore, if seeds are desired, both a male and female plant must be grown.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: <!--Detail here when and how the species was discovered or first circumscribed. Tell any background to this description or establishment. Mention its etymology, its type specimen if known. Consider adding the original authority as a reference.

column5: 蓝]]}} in China. The plant was first described in 1406 CE by [[Zhu Xiao]], who presented a description and sketch in the book ''Materia Medica for Famine'' as a [[survival food]] rather than a medicinal herb.<ref>{{cite journal
column7: title=Investigation of the plant jiaogulan and its analogous herb, Wulianmei
column12: pages=424}}</ref> The earliest record of jiaogulan's use as a drug comes from herbalist [[Li Shizhen]]'s book ''[[Compendium of Materia Medica]]'' published in 1578, identifying jiaogulan for treating various ailments such as [[hematuria]], [[edema]] in the pharynx and neck, [[Neoplasm
column14: trauma]]. While Li Shizhen had confused jiaogulan with an analogous herb [[Wulianmei]], in 1848 [[Wu Qi-Jun]] rectified this confusion in ''Textual Investigation of Herbal Plants''.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Modern recognition of the plant outside of China originated from research in [[sugar substitute]]s.<ref name=drugs/> In the 1970s, while analyzing the sweet component of the jiaogulan plant (known as ''amachazuru'' in Japan), [[Masahiro Nagai]] discovered [[saponin]]s identical to those in ''Panax ginseng''.<ref>{{cite conference
column3: title=Abstracts of Papers, 23d Meeting of the Japanese Society of Pharmacognosy
column10: id= }}</ref> Continued research has described several more saponins ([[gypenoside]]s) comparable or identical to those found in ginseng.<ref name=\"drugs\" /> ''Panax ginseng'' contains [[ginsenoside]]s while [[gypenoside]] saponins have been found in jiaogulan.<ref name=\"drugs\" />

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: ''G. pentaphyllum'' is one of about 17 species in the genus ''Gynostemma'', including nine species [[endemic]] to China.<ref name=FoC-genus/> However, ''G. pentaphyllum'' has a wide distribution outside of China, ranging from India and Bangladesh to Southeast Asia to Japan and Korea as well as to New Guinea.<ref name=FoC-species/> In China, it grows in forests, thickets, and roadsides on mountain slopes at elevations of {{convert
Jiaogulan is a vine hardy to [[Hardiness zone
British businessman}}: USDA zone]] 8 in which it may grow as a short lived [[perennial plant]].<ref name=drugs/> It can be grown as an annual in most temperate climates, in well-drained soil with full sun. It does not grow well in cold climates with temperatures below freezing.<ref name=drugs/>

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Constituents of ''G. pentaphyllum'' include [[sterol]]s, [[saponin]], [[flavonoid]]s, and [[chlorophyll]].<ref name=drugs/> [[Gypenoside]]s have been [[extract
British businessman}}: extracted]] from its leaves.<ref name=drugs/> Some saponin compounds are the same as those found in [[ginseng]] roots.<ref name=drugs/>Severe nausea and increased bowel movements have been reported; however, a clinical trial using jiaogulan tea 6 g/day reported no adverse effects <ref name=drugs/>

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Gynostemma pnetaphyllum has been investigated extensively as a potent anti-cancer agent against many types of cancers both in vitro and in vivo. <ref name=anticancer/>
The plant is used in folk medicine, typically as an [[herbal tea]], but may be used as an [[tincture
British businessman}}: alcohol extract]] or in [[dietary supplement]]s. It has not seen widespread use in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] (TCM), being adopted only in the past 20 years,<ref name=\"drugs\" /> because it grows far from central China where TCM evolved; consequently, it was not included in the standard [[pharmacopoeia]] of the TCM system. Before then, it was a locally-known herb used primarily in mountainous regions of southern China and in northern Vietnam. It is described by the local inhabitants as the \"immortality herb\", because a large number of elderly people within [[Guizhou]] Province reported consuming the plant regularly.<ref name=drugs/><ref name=\"Bensky\">{{cite book
column8: title = Chinese Herbal Medicine: Materia Medica
column13: isbn = 978-0-939616-42-8 }}</ref> In the [[European Union]], jiaogulan is considered a [[novel food]] following a 2012 court ruling that prohibited its sale as food.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Jiaogulan ist als Lebensmittel in Deutschland und somit auch in der ganzen Europäischen Union nun offiziell verboten!

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Some limited research has assessed the potential for jiaogulan to affect such disorders as [[cardiovascular diseases]], [[hyperlipidemia]], or [[type 2 diabetes]],<ref>{{cite journal
British businessman}}: title=Antidiabetic effect of ''Gynostemma pentaphyllum'' tea in randomly assigned type 2 diabetic patients
column3: vauthors=Huyen VT, Phan DV, Thang P, Hoa NK, Ostenson CG
column11: hdl=10616/40703 }}</ref> but these studies were too preliminary to allow any conclusion that it was beneficial.<ref name=drugs/>

column3: 绞股蓝}}}}, [[Pinyin]]: jiǎogǔlán, literally \"twisting blue plant\"), is a [[dioecious]], [[herbaceous]] climbing [[vine]] of the family [[Cucurbitaceae]] ([[cucumber]] or [[gourd]] family) widely distributed in South and East Asia as well as New Guinea. Jiaogulan has recently been incorporated into [[traditional medicine]], although there is no [[evidence-based medicine]] that demonstrates any effects on human health.<ref name=\"drugs\">{{cite web

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Among many common names are five-leaf ginseng, poor man's ginseng, miracle grass, fairy herb, sweet tea vine, gospel herb, and southern ginseng.<ref name=drugs/>
Jiaogulan belongs to the genus ''[[Gynostemma]]'', in the family [[Cucurbitaceae]], which includes [[cucumber]]s, [[gourd]]s, and [[melon]]s.<ref name=\"FoC-genus\">{{cite web
column8: publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis, MO & Harvard University Herbaria, Cambridge, MA
column16: publisher=Missouri Botanical Garden, St. Louis, MO & Harvard University Herbaria, Cambridge, MA
column17: accessdate=2 May 2018}}</ref> Its fruit is a small purple inedible gourd. It is a climbing vine, attaching itself to supports using [[tendril]]s. The serrated leaflets commonly grow in groups of five (as in ''G. pentaphyllum'') although some species can have groups of three or seven leaflets. The plant is [[dioecious]], meaning each plant exists either as male or female. Therefore, if seeds are desired, both a male and female plant must be grown.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''Fort Valley''' is a [[mountain]] [[valley]] in [[Shenandoah County, Virginia
column5: December 12, 2016}}</ref>  It is often called \"valley within a valley\" as it lies between the two arms of the northern [[Massanutten Mountain]] range in the [[Shenandoah Valley]], which are part of the  in the [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]].  The eastern ridgeline of Fort Valley is named Massanutten Mountain and is basically continuous for the eastern length of Fort Valley.  The western ridgeline of the valley is composed of three named mountains, from north to south: Three Top Mountain, Powell Mountain and Short Mountain. Additionally, behind Three Top and Powell mountains another ridgeline in the chain is called Green Mountain, which has a smaller valley called Little Fort Valley between it and the western ridgelines. In addition, there are several other named smaller mountains and promontories within Forth Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is almost entirely enclosed. At its southern end it is enclosed with an access point called Moreland Gap, and to the north it is constricted and nearly closed but for where [[Passage Creek]] flows through a narrow gap providing passage towards Front Royal. Passage Creek also is a prominent element of Fort Valley, running the entire length of the entire valley at its center, starting in Crishman Hollow in the mountains in the south and flowing north, aided by other streams and runs, until it exits Fort Valley just past Elizabeth Furnace. The valley opens out toward the center, becoming about {{convert
column4: spell=in}} wide at its widest. The extreme southern end of the valley, the highlands of Crishman Hollow, is in Page County. The remainder of Fort Valley is in Shenandoah County, with the border of Shenandoah and Page counties being along the eastern ridgeline of Masanutten Mountain.  In all, Fort Valley is {{convert

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is entirely rural, consisting mostly of private farmland, surrounded by the [[George Washington National Forest]] (GWNF), which covers the slopes and ridges on both the east and west mountains. The [[Elizabeth Furnace]] and [[Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area]] of the GWNF are located within Fort Valley.

Between Three Top, Powell and Green Mountain there are two gaps, Mine Gap and Woodstock Gap, the latter of which features a dirt road, Rt 758, from the town of  Woodstock to the Woodstock Tower, which sits on the ridge of Powell Mountain offering panoramic views of the town and the Shenandoah Valley. Woodstock Tower is a historic observation post built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1935.

Between Powell and Short mountains is Edinburg Gap, a more frequently traveled paved road that offers primary access from the west into Fort Valley. At the top of Edinburg Gap on the southern side there is an extensive all terrain vehicle (ATV) trail system set up by the Forest Service. On the northern side of the gap starts Peter's Mill Road, an off-highway vehicle (OHV) road made available for jeeps and four wheel drive vehicles. Peter's Mill Road runs from Edinburg Gap to Woodstock Gap along the higher reaches of the Little Fort Valley. In the east, Fort Valley is accessed via a paved road through Edith Gap that also serves as entrance to Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area. There are no roads accessing Fort Valley on the east, over Massanutten Mountain, from Camp Roosevelt to Elizabeth furnace at the northern apex of the valley.
Roads exit the valley at its northern end ([[Virginia State Route 678
column4: Front Royal]], at Edinburg Gap ([[Virginia State Route 675
column8: New Market]], and Edith Gap (S.R. 675) towards [[Luray, Virginia
column9: Luray]]. There is also the dirt road that leads to [[Woodstock, Virginia

British businessman}}: Tuscarora trail]], a 252-mile long distance hiking trail that passes through Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, proceeds along the northeast ridgeline of Fort Valley, entering from just above Shenandoah State Park on the eastern ridgeline of Massanutten Mountain. The hiking trail passes through the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area, ascends Green Mountain and exits on Doll's Ridge on the western slope of Three Top Mountain as it descends towards the [[Tom's Brook Battlefield]] in the Shenandoah Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: The [[Massanutten Trail]] circumnavigates the entire ridgeline of the Fort Valley, 71 miles in total. It was built by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC), completed in 2001. Prior to 2001, different portions of the trail had been known by different names and blazed in different colors. With the completion of the missing links, the Forest Service renamed the combined trails as the Massanutten Trail and provided orange blazes along the trail's entire length around Fort Valley.

Fort Valley features two developed U.S. Forest Service recreation areas, [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73687 Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area] toward the northern apex of the Valley, and [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73633 Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area] at Edith Gap in the southeast end of the valley. Both recreation areas were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s. Camp Roosevelt features a hang gliding site nearby, a pavilion, camp sites and access to the Masanutten Trail.  Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area features a pavilion and multiple camping areas, interpretive trails related the historical iron industry at the site, and acess to the Masanutten and Tuscarora trails which share a length of trail leading to Elizabeth Furnace from the east and separate at Elizabeth Furnace north (Massanutten Trail) and west (Tuscarora Trail.)

According to tradition, [[Daniel Morgan]] built the first road into Fort Valley from the north, at the order of [[George Washington]], with a view to holing up in this naturally fortified valley as a possible last stand against the [[British Army
British businessman}}: British]] during the [[American Revolution]]. The [[Continental Army]]'s victory at [[Siege of Yorktown

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[Elizabeth Furnace]] was a blast furnace in the Shenandoah Valley that created pig iron from 1836 – 1888, using Passage Creek for water power. Iron ore was mined in the mountains, purified in the furnace, then pig iron was transported transported over Massanutten Mountain to the South Fork of the Shenandoah River, where it was transported for forging in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The road used to transport the iron is in use today as a hiking trail. At one time, Elizabeth Furnace supported a community associated with the local iron industry. Elizabeth Furnace was destroyed by Union troops in 1864 during operations associated with the [[Battle of Cedar Creek]]. The furnace reopened in 1883 but lacked sufficient output and was abandoned in 1888. The Elizabeth Furnace Cabin is one of the few wooden buildings remaining from the early 1800s when Elizabeth Furnace was active. <ref>https://shenandoahcountyva.us/tourism/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2014/01/Elizabeth_Furnace_rec_Area_info_booklet-sm-res1.pdf</ref>. In 1936 the Civilian Conservation Corps constructed the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area on the site.

Signal Knob, a 2,111 foot barren promontory at the extreme northern ridgeline of Fort Valley that offers sweeping and unobstructed panoramic views of of the Shenandoah Valley northeast and west, was utilized during a Civil War as a strategic military observation post. The observation post can view the nearby Shenandoah Valley battlefields of Cedar Creek, [[Fisher's Hill]] and Tom's Brook. It's accessed by an 11.5 mile round-trip hike from Elizabeth Furnace.
The [[Daniel Munch House]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2002.<ref name=\"nris\">{{NRISref

It was built by the Potomac Appalachian Trail Club (PATC), completed in 2001. Prior to 2001, different portions of the trail had been known by different names and blazed in different colors. With the completion of the missing links, the Forest Service renamed the combined trails as the Massanutten Trail and provided orange blazes along the trail's entire length around Fort Valley.

Fort Valley features two developed U.S. Forest Service recreation areas, [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73687 Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area] toward the northern apex of the Valley, and [https://www.fs.usda.gov/recarea/gwj/recarea/?recid=73633 Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area] at Edith Gap in the southeast end of the valley. Both recreation areas were built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in the 1930s. Camp Roosevelt features a hang gliding site nearby, a pavilion, camp sites and access to the Masanutten Trail.  Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area features a pavilion and multiple camping areas, interpretive trails related the historical iron industry at the site, and acess to the Masanutten and Tuscarora trails which share a length of trail leading to Elizabeth Furnace from the east and separate at Elizabeth Furnace north (Massanutten Trail) and west (Tuscarora Trail.)

According to tradition, [[Daniel Morgan]] built the first road into Fort Valley from the north, at the order of [[George Washington]], with a view to holing up in this naturally fortified valley as a possible last stand against the [[British Army
British businessman}}: British]] during the [[American Revolution]]. The [[Continental Army]]'s victory at [[Siege of Yorktown

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[Elizabeth Furnace]] was a blast furnace in the Shenandoah Valley that created pig iron from 1836 – 1888, using Passage Creek for water power. Iron ore was mined in the mountains, purified in the furnace, then pig iron was transported transported over Massanutten Mountain to the South Fork of the Shenandoah River, where it was transported for forging in Harpers Ferry, West Virginia. The road used to transport the iron is in use today as a hiking trail. At one time, Elizabeth Furnace supported a community associated with the local iron industry. Elizabeth Furnace was destroyed by Union troops in 1864 during operations associated with the [[Battle of Cedar Creek]]. The furnace reopened in 1883 but lacked sufficient output and was abandoned in 1888. The Elizabeth Furnace Cabin is one of the few wooden buildings remaining from the early 1800s when Elizabeth Furnace was active. <ref>https://shenandoahcountyva.us/tourism/wp-content/uploads/sites/16/2014/01/Elizabeth_Furnace_rec_Area_info_booklet-sm-res1.pdf</ref>. In 1936 the Civilian Conservation Corps constructed the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area on the site.

Signal Knob, a 2,111 foot barren promontory at the extreme northern ridgeline of Fort Valley that offers sweeping and unobstructed panoramic views of of the Shenandoah Valley northeast and west, was utilized during a Civil War as a strategic military observation post. The observation post can view the nearby Shenandoah Valley battlefields of Cedar Creek, [[Fisher's Hill]] and Tom's Brook. It's accessed by an 11.5 mile round-trip hike from Elizabeth Furnace.
The [[Daniel Munch House]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2002.<ref name=\"nris\">{{NRISref

British businessman}}: photo_caption = Air photo of Fort Valley, facing south, with the North (right) and South (left) Forks of the [[Shenandoah River]] visible.  February 2009.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''Fort Valley''' is a [[mountain]] [[valley]] in [[Shenandoah County, Virginia
column5: December 12, 2016}}</ref>  The so-called \"valley within a valley\" lies between the two arms of the northern [[Massanutten Mountain]] range in the [[Shenandoah Valley]], part of the  in the [[Ridge-and-Valley Appalachians]].  The eastern ridgeline of the valley is named Massanuten and is basicallyt continuous for the eastern length of Fort Valley.  The western ridgeline of the valley is composed of three named mountains, from north to south: Three Top Mountain, Powell Mountain and Short Mountain. Additionally, behind Three Top and Powell mountains another ridgeline in the chain is called Green Mountain, which has a smaller valley called Little Fort Valley between it and the western ridgelines. In addition, there are several other named smaller mountains and promontories within Forth Valley.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is almost entirely enclosed. At its southern end it is enclosed with an access point called Moreland Gap, and to the north it is constricted and nearly closed but for where [[Passage Creek]] flows through a narrow gap providing passage towards Front Royal. Passage Creek also is a prominent element of Fort Valley, running the entire length of the entire valley at its center, starting in Crishman Hollow in the mountains in the south and flowing north, aided by other streams and runs, until it exits Fort Valley just past Elizabeth Furnace. The valley opens out toward the center, becoming about {{convert
column4: spell=in}} wide at its widest. The extreme southern end of the valley, the highlands of Crishman Hollow, is in Page County. The remainder of Fort Valley is in Shenandoah County, with the border of Shenandoah and Page counties being along the eastern ridgeline of Masanutten Mountain.  In all, Fort Valley is {{convert

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Fort Valley is entirely rural, consisting mostly of private farmland, surrounded by the [[George Washington National Forest]] (GWNF), which covers the slopes and ridges on both the east and west mountains. The [[Elizabeth Furnace]] and [[Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area]] of the GWNF are located within Fort Valley.

Between Three Top, Powell and Green Mountain there are two gaps, Mine Gap and Woodstock Gap, the latter of which features a dirt road, Rt 758, from the town of  Woodstock to the Woodstock Tower, which sits on the ridge of Powell Mountain offering panoramic views of the town and the Shenandoah Valley. Woodstock Tower is a historic observation post built by the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1935.

Between Powell and Short mountains is Edinburg Gap, a more frequently traveled paved road that offers primary access from the west into Fort Valley. At the top of Edinburg Gap on the southern side there is an extensive all terrain vehicle (ATV) trail system set up by the Forest Service. On the northern side of the gap starts Peter's Mill Road, an off-highway vehicle (OHV) road made available for jeeps and four wheel drive vehicles. Peter's Mill Road runs from Edinburg Gap to Woodstock Gap along the higher reaches of the Little Fort Valley. In the east, Fort Valley is accessed via a paved road through Edith Gap that also serves as entrance to Camp Roosevelt Recreation Area. There are no roads accessing Fort Valley on the east, over Massanutten Mountain, from Camp Roosevelt to Elizabeth furnace at the northern apex of the valley.
Roads exit the valley at its northern end ([[Virginia State Route 678
column4: Front Royal]], at Edinburg Gap ([[Virginia State Route 675
column8: New Market]], and Edith Gap (S.R. 675) towards [[Luray, Virginia
column9: Luray]]. There is also the dirt road that leads to [[Woodstock, Virginia

British businessman}}: Tuscarora trail]], a 252-mile long distance hiking trail that passes through Virginia, West Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania, proceeds along the northeast ridgeline of Fort Valley, entering from just above Shenandoah State Park on the eastern ridgeline of Massanutten Mountain. The hiking trail passes through the Elizabeth Furnace Recreation Area, ascends Green Mountain and exits on Doll's Ridge on the western slope of Three Top Mountain as it descends towards the [[Tom's Brook Battlefield]] in the Shenandoah Valley.

'''Burleigh \"Buck\" Johnson''' is an American singer-songwriter and multi-instrumentalist, performing as a backing vocalist, keyboardist and acoustic guitarist with [[Aerosmith]],<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Touring with Aerosmith, new solo CD have Alabama's Buck Johnson living rock-star dream - Alabama NewsCenter
column7: language=en-US}}</ref> [[The Hollywood Vampires]] ([[Johnny Depp]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Joe Perry (musician)
column9: Joe Perry]].  He was co-vocalist and keyboardist for the Country-Rock group [[Whiskey Falls]] ([[Midas Records Nashville
column10: Midas Records]]).  Johnson released his self titled album in 2016 on Spectra Music Group and tours with his band as a solo artist.  He has had songs placed in TV, Film and recorded by other artist including the international hit single by [[Carlos Santana]], “[[Just Feel Better]]”, featuring [[Steven Tyler]] on lead vocals.<ref>{{Cite news
column12: title=Aerosmith's secret weapon: Alabama native on tour with rock legends

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Buck Johnson was raised outside of Birmingham, AL in a town called Shady Grove. He began performing at an early age, singing Gospel music with his family throughout the South. While attending Birmingham-Southern College, Buck met his wife, Kym, and they relocated to Los Angeles, CA.<ref name=\":0\" />

In Los Angeles, Johnson toured and recorded with such acts as [[The Doobie Brothers]], [[Chris Stills]], [[Tal Bachman]], [[John Waite]], [[Matthew Sweet]], [[Shawn Mullins]], [[The Thorns]], and [[Timothy B. Schmit]] ([[Eagles (band)
British businessman}}: The Eagles]]).  He has worked as a songwriting collaborator, session vocalist and musician with songwriter/producers Jamie Houston ([[Carlos Santana]], [[Jon McLaughlin
column3: Jon McLaughlan]]), and [[Charlie Midnight]] ([[The Doobie Brothers]]).<ref>{{Cite web
column5: title=We3Kings Music - Song Writing, Music Production, Artist & Brand Development

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: As a songwriter, Johnson co-wrote the international hit single “[[Just Feel Better]]” with Jamie Houston and [[Damon Johnson]] for [[Carlos Santana]] on his 2005 album ''[[All That I Am (Santana album)
British businessman}}: All That I Am]]'', featuring [[Steven Tyler]] on lead vocals.<ref name=\":0\" />

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: In 2006, Buck joined the Country-Rock band [[Whiskey Falls]] as a principle songwriter, co-vocalist and multi-instrumentalist, and moved to Nashville, TN. [[Whiskey Falls]] released their self-titled album on [[Midas Records Nashville
British businessman}}: Midas Records]] in 2007, earning 2 Country Top 40 hit singles, “Last Train Running” and “Falling Into You”.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite news
column4: title=Touring with Aerosmith, new solo CD have Alabama's Buck Johnson living rock-star dream - Alabama NewsCenter

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: In 2014, Johnson was asked to join [[Aerosmith]] on their European and North American tours on keyboard, acoustic guitarist and backing vocals. Of Johnson's inclusion into the band, [[Steven Tyler]] commented, \"Buck Johnson came in out of the blue and purely by chance to our Aerosmith family, and we feel we really won the lottery. ''Big''. Turns out he's much, much more than just a guy to sing harmony with. He plays slammin' guitar and is out of this world on anything keys. He's a true all-around talent, a huge asset to me and Aerosmith and also a great human being and friend.”<ref>{{Cite news
column3: title=Aerosmith's secret weapon: Alabama native on tour with rock legends
column8: title=Aerosmith Still Living on the Edge at the Forum: Concert Review

Born in [[Princeton, NJ]], Anselmo spent the majority of his childhood in nearby [[Freehold Township, New Jersey
British businessman}}: Freehold, NJ]] (more specifically, in the suburb of [[Millstone Township, New Jersey
column3: Millstone Township, NJ]]). His first extended venture into songwriting happened at Allentown High School, when he wrote a book report on ''[[David Copperfield]]'' as a song cycle.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title = NJ writers join the New York Musical Theatre Festival
column7: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> Anselmo moved to [[East Greenwich, RI]] after his sophomore year of high school;<ref>{{Cite web
column8: title = ‘Fable’ is no fairy tale; play to have NYC debut {{!}} June 5, 2014 {{!}} exa.gmnews.com {{!}} Examiner

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Anselmo is best known for his musical ''Fable'', co-written with his childhood friend, Harrison Kaufman. Originally written by Anselmo after his high school graduation as a song cycle, he brought Kaufman on to write a script, which would help to transform the collection of songs into a full-length musical.<ref>{{Cite web
British businessman}}: title = Musical Co-Authored by PHS Alum Selected by Musical Theater Festival {{!}} Town Topics
column5: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> The pair developed the material at [[French Woods Festival of the Performing Arts]] and workshopped the show for two years with organizations such as Arts Alliance at Northwestern and the Actors Training Center in [[Wilmette, IL]] before submitting it to the [[New York Musical Theatre Festival]] (more colloquially known as NYMF). Out of hundreds of submissions, ''Fable'' was among ten shows selected for NYMF's Next Link Project,<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title = Q&A: Christopher Anselmo, co-creator of ‘Fable’
column9: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> and was granted a fully staged production Off-Broadway at the 2014 edition of the festival.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: ''Fable'' ran at the Pershing Square Signature Center from July 22–27, 2014; the show's run was extended twice.<ref>{{Cite web
British businessman}}: title = Both Cloned! and Fable Extend at NYMF in First Week
column6: title = NYMF's FABLE Extends Again; Comes to 54 Below, 7/17
column9: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> Anselmo's score was widely lauded by critics as \"clever and oddly endearing,\"<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title = Review: Fable {{!}} Times Square Chronicles
column22: archivedate = 2015-08-27}}</ref> and \"by turns soaring, jaunty, and hard-rocking.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column23: title = Reviews - 2014 New York Musical Theater Festival (NYMF) - Part 4
column25: website = Everything I Know I Learned From Musicals

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Anselmo and Kaufman are the youngest writers ever to be accepted to the festival in history; both were twenty years old on opening night.<ref>{{Cite web
British businessman}}: title = FABLE Makes History at NYMF, 7/22-27

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Commissioned by Unmasked Theater Company, Anselmo wrote music and lyrics for the world premiere production of ''The Haunted Train'' (book by Christian Fleming and Randy Gross).
The show was produced Off-Off-Broadway at Theater for the New City from October 14–18, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web
British businessman}}: title = Unmasked Theatre to Stage THE HAUNTED TRAIN at TNC This October
column5: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> Nickolaus Hines of OnstageBlog wrote that Anselmo's score is \"A warm wave of perfect harmony\" which is \"critical to the piece.... it almost comes off as a set of musical numbers interrupted by lines.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column6: title = Review: \"The Haunted Train\" at Theater for the New City

As a director, he has helmed established musicals, like ''[[Spamalot]]'', while also developing new works, like ''Fight or Flight'' (a song cycle).<ref>{{Cite web
British businessman}}: title = Q&A: The Daily speaks with ‘Spamalot’ director about gender changes in the musical
column6: title = Songs of Themselves: Reviewing ‘The Lilliput Troupe’ and ‘Fight or Flight’
column9: accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref> He has also contributed to Northwestern's [[a cappella]] community, performing and arranging (and formerly serving as musical director) with Freshman Fifteen, an all-male a cappella group.<ref>{{Cite web

British businessman}}: occupation    = Author, Buddhist scholar and language activist

column4: Cover of ''Buddha Dharma wa Nepal Bhasa'' (\"Buddhism and Nepalese\") magazine dated August 1929.]]

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: '''Dharmaditya Dharmacharya''' ([[Devanagari]]: धर्मादित्य धर्माचार्य) (born '''Jagat Man Vaidya''') (1902–1963) was a Nepalese author, Buddhist scholar and language activist. He worked to develop [[Nepal Bhasa]] and revive [[Theravada Buddhism]] when Nepal was ruled by the [[Rana dynasty]] and both were dangerous activities, and was consequently jailed.<ref>Singh, Harischandra Lal (1996). ''Reflections on Buddhism of the Kathmandu Valley.'' Kathmandu: Educational Enterprise. Pages 5–7.</ref><ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Buddhist Monks and Rana Rulers: A History of Persecution
column7: newspaper=Buddhist Himalaya: A Journal of Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Dharmacharya campaigned for [[Nepal Era]] as the national calendar. He also wrote and published the first magazine in Nepal Bhasa and was a major influence in the [[Nepal Bhasa renaissance]].<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=A Historical Study of Pariyatti Sikkhâ in Nepal
column12: url-status=dead}} Pages 15–16.</ref><ref>Bajracharya, Phanindra Ratna (2003). ''Who's Who in Nepal Bhasha.'' Kathmandu: Nepal Bhasa Academy. Page 36.</ref> Because of his service to the language, he has also been called the \"fifth pillar\" of Nepal Bhasa along with the [[Four Pillars of Nepal Bhasa]].

column3: Lalitpur District]] to father Vaidya Vrishman Vandya and mother Muni Thakun Vandya. He studied at [[Durbar High School]] in [[Kathmandu]] and did his matriculation from [[Kolkata]] and enrolled at the [[University of Calcutta]] for higher studies.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: On his visits to Kathmandu during the holidays, he organized Buddhist programs and exhibitions of religious pictures he had collected in Kolkata. In 1924, he established the Buddha Dharma Support Association at the home of [[Dharma Man Tuladhar]]. He encouraged its members to read Buddhist books and translated articles in English and [[Pali]] into Nepal Bhasa.

Upon his return to Kolkata, he established the Nepalese Buddhist Association to help Nepalese traders who had fallen into difficulty besides teaching them Buddhist principles. In 1928, he helped organize the All India Buddhist Conference.<ref>{{cite news
column5: newspaper=Buddhist Himalaya: A Journal of Nagarjuna Institute of Exact Methods

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: In an effort to promote Buddhism among the Nepalese in [[Darjeeling]], he brought out ''Himalaya Bauddha'' in the [[Nepali language]] and ''Buddhist India'' in English in 1927 which he and B. M. Barua ([[Benimadhab Barua]]) edited.<ref>Hridaya, Chittadhar (1982, third ed.) ''Jheegu Sahitya'' (\"Our Literature\"). Kathmandu: Nepal Bhasa Parisad. Page 172.</ref><ref>Sen, Jahar and Indian Institute of Advanced Study (1992). ''India and Nepal: Some aspects of culture contact.'' Indian Institute of Advanced Study. {{ISBN

Dharmacharya was a cultural nationalist and dedicated himself to promoting Nepal Bhasa and obtaining international recognition for it.<ref>Lecomte-Tilouine, Marie and Dollfus, Pascale (2003) ''Ethnic Revival and Religious Turmoil: Identities and Representations in the Himalayas.'' Oxford University Press. {{ISBN

In 1925, he published ''[[Buddha Dharma wa Nepal Bhasa]]'' (बुद्ध धर्म व नॆपाल भाषा \"Buddhism and Nepalese\") from Kolkata, India. It was the first ever magazine to be published in Nepal Bhasa.<ref>LeVine, Sarah and Gellner, David N. (2005) ''Rebuilding Buddhism: The Theravada Movement in Twentieth-Century Nepal.'' Harvard University Press. {{ISBN
British businessman}}: 978-0-674-01908-9}}. Pages 27–28. Retrieved 2 February 2012.</ref> It contained articles on Buddhism and also provided writers in Nepal a place to publish their compositions which they couldn't do at home because of the government's dislike of the language.<ref>Lienhard, Siegfried (1992). ''Songs of Nepal: An Anthology of Nevar Folksongs and Hymns.'' New Delhi: Motilal Banarsidas. {{ISBN

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: In order to support the emerging Nepal Bhasa movement in Nepal and promote the language at home and abroad, he established the first Nepal Bhasa literary organization Nepal Bhasa Sahitya Mandal (\"Nepal Bhasa Literature Organization\") in Kolkata in 1926.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=The Newars: The Indigenous Population of the Kathmandu Valley in the Modern State of Nepal)

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Dharmacharya returned to Kathmandu with a master's degree in Pali. He joined the Industry Council as an administrative officer and married Asta Maya and settled down into the life of a householder.

In 1940, Dharmacharya was arrested in a crackdown against democracy activists, writers and social reformers. He was jailed for three months with other Nepal Bhasa writers. Following the incident, he remained inactive in social work for more than five years. He spent the later part of his life lecturing and writing.<ref>LeVine, Sarah and Gellner, David N. (2005) ''Rebuilding Buddhism: The Theravada Movement in Twentieth-Century Nepal.'' Harvard University Press. {{ISBN

column4: Bust of Dharmaditya Dharmacharya at Pulchok, Lalitpur.]]

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: In 1956, Dharmacharya was decorated with the title of Patron of the Language by Chwasa Pasa.<ref>Hridaya, Chittadhar (1982, third ed.) ''Jheegu Sahitya'' (\"Our Literature\"). Kathmandu: Nepal Bhasa Parisad. Page 192.</ref> A statue of Dharmacharya has been erected at Pulchok, Lalipur.
[[Category:Buddhist writers]]","{{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. -->

'''Desmond \"Des\" Kelly''' (born 19 February 1965) is a British journalist and broadcaster.

Kelly is the lead reporter and interviewer for British broadcaster, BT Sport. He is part of the live broadcast team for the channel's Champions League, Premier League, Europa League and FA Cup coverage. He has been nominated as SJA Broadcast Journalist of the Year for 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019 - and highly commended in 2017 and 2018.<ref>{{cite web

Kelly previously presented over 150 editions of a live, late-night sport/entertainment show on [[BT Sport]] called ''Follow the Football with Des Kelly'' previously known as ''Life's A Pitch with Des Kelly''. He was also executive producer of the programme, which originally launched on 5 August 2013 and was nominated for SJA Television Show of the Year in 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Des Kelly presents Life's a Pitch
column4: publisher=}}</ref> Kelly simultaneously presented SportsHUB, BT Sport's sports news programme, from Monday to Thursday, until the show closed in 2015.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Kelly was a long-standing presenter on [[talkSPORT]], the commercial national radio station which broadcasts from London across the United Kingdom. He is the former host of ''The Press Pass'', a show introduced on the first weekend of the Premier League season in August 2011. It was twice nominated as SJA Sports Radio Programme of the Year. He quit in August 2014 to concentrate on his BT commitments, but is still an occasional presenter and contributor.

A past winner of the SJA Sports Columnist of the Year award, Kelly was nominated as ''UK Press Gazette'' Sports Writer of the Year and commended on four separate occasions by the Sports Journalists' Association for his articles.

In 2012 Kelly was named among the top 10 most influential sportswriters in Britain by the trade publication, UK Press Gazette.<ref name = \"UKPG Names Top Sports Journalists\">In 2012 Samuel was named top in a UK Press Gazette poll of Britain's best sports journalists.</ref>
Kelly was a sports columnist on the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' for nearly a decade, having joined the paper in 2004.

Previously, Kelly was the Acting Editor and Deputy Editor of the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''. Kelly replaced [[Piers Morgan]] after he was sacked for publishing faked photos of Iraqi prisoners being \"tortured\" by British troops<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3716151.stm Editor sacked over 'hoax' photos] BBC News 14 May 2004</ref> and edited the paper in the wake of that controversy.  Kelly was also 'forced out' of the ''Mirror'' later in 2004 when Richard Wallace was handed the position.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Des Kelly: My Life In Media

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: A contributor to [[Sky News]] and [[BBC Breakfast]], he is also a regular member of the [[BBC Radio Five Live]] ''[[Fighting Talk]]'' panel show and has appeared on ''[[Sportsweek]]'' and the [[BBC Radio 4]] ''[[Today programme]]''.

He is a former Assistant Editor and Head of Sport of the ''[[Daily Express]]'', football editor of the ''[[Sunday Express]]'', and the Chief Sports Reporter of the now defunct ''[[Today (UK newspaper)
British businessman}}: Today]]'' newspaper. He was previously a columnist for ''[[The Sunday Times (UK)
column3: The Sunday Times]]'' and had a column in the ''London Evening Standard''. He has also has written for ''[[GQ]]'', German newspaper ''[[Bild]]'' and ''[[L'Équipe]]'' in France.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Kelly was part of the [[BBC1]]'s ''[[Inside Sport (TV series)
British businessman}}: Inside Sport]]'' presenting team, which was hosted by [[Gabby Logan]] between 2007 and 2009. His contributions included interviews with [[Michael Schumacher]],<ref>{{cite web
column11: work=BBC Sport}}</ref> and a piece on GB Blind Football.<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=Inside Sport: Des Kelly tries blind football

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Des has made television appearances on the BBC's ''[[Match of the Day
British businessman}}: Match of the Day 2]]'' and was the first journalist to appear as a pundit on either show. He has also guested on [[Channel 4]]'s [[Clive Anderson]]'s ''Sports Talk Show'', [[Sky Sports]]' ''Hold the Back Page'' show and one of his first assignments was to provide live reports for [[Sky News]] from [[England national football team
column3: England's]] 3–0 win over [[Poland national football team
column4: Poland]] in 1989. He has been a contributor to a number of programmes, including BBC's ''The Noughties... Was That It?'' and ''Britain's Most Annoying People'' as well as [[GMTV]] and others.

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Kelly is patron of the Great Britain Blind Football team and opened the new [[Royal National College for the Blind]] Paralympic Centre in [[Hereford]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=State-of-the-art facility makes an impressive bow
column6: title=BBC personality Des Kelly launches thePoint4
column7: publisher=}}</ref> He is also a member of the Jaguar Sports Academy and is on the judging panel for the [[Laureus World Sports Awards]].

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Kelly has also been an Executive Consultant for the PR agency [[Hill & Knowlton]] and director of the internet company [[Fast Web Media]]. At Hill and Knowlton he was Master of Ceremonies at various corporate nights involving supermodels [[Jerry Hall]] and [[Petra Nemcova]], football manager [[Arsène Wenger]], the [[BBC]] ''[[Match of the Day]]'' team, [[Cilla Black]], chef [[Antony Worrall Thompson]], the cricketers [[Nasser Hussain
British businessman}}: Nasser Hussein]] and [[Jeff Thomson]] and footballer [[Marcel Desailly]].

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: He has completed two [[London Marathon]]s, the Network Q [[Rally of Great Britain]] twice,<ref>[http://www.rallybase.nl/index.php?type=result&rallyid=68 RallyBase<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Network Q Rally of Great Britain 2000 Entry List
column4: publisher=}}</ref> the Arctic Rally, the [[Belgium]] Bianchi Rally and others. He took part in the world's first two-seater F1 race with [[Fernando Alonso]] at [[Donington Park]]. He completed in the 2007 Isle of Wight Round The Island race on board an [[Extreme 40]] sailing boat, made a parachute jump for MENCAP, has run with the bulls in Pamplona and climbed Kilimanjaro as part of a Football League team raising funds for Marie Curie Cancer Care in the summer of 2011.{{citation needed

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: Kelly lives in [[Bristol]]. Born in London of an Irish family, he was educated at [[Wimbledon College]] and has a University of Surrey BA (Hons) in English and History from [[Froebel College]] in [[Roehampton]], London.<ref>{{cite web

He is married to dress designer Paulina. Their engagement was announced in The Times on 26 December 2014. They married on 17 June 2015 at the Bristol Planetarium. TV presenter [[Carol Vorderman]] is a former girlfriend. They lived together in central London from early 2001 and split in December 2006. They rekindled the relationship in October 2007 but split again in 2010.{{citation needed

→‎top:Cleanup andtypo fixing,typo(s) fixed: a oil → an oil,safe,Iridescent,"Below is a brief timeline covering the '''history of the petroleum industry [[Alberta]]''' and its predecessor states.

British businessman}}: [[Captain Swan]] reports finding \"gum or pitch\" in the region now known as the [[Athabasca oil sands
column3: Athabasca oil sand]]. The Captain's report is the first known to mention the oil sands.

British businessman}}: [[George Mercer Dawson]] files the first government report of the oil sands when surveying for the [[International Boundary Commission]].
The [[Rocky Mountain Development Company]] drills the first oil producing well, [[Lineham Discovery Well No. 1]], in [[Western Canada]] at Cameron Creek.

column4: title=How the West was Won: Alberta’s First Oil Well

British businessman}}: The ''[[Alberta Act]]'' creates Alberta as a province from the [[Northwest Territories
column3: North-West Territories]]. Resource rights are still held by the federal government.

British businessman}}: [[Dingman No. 1]] strikes oil starting an oil boom that subsides due to [[World War I]].

[[Public Utilities Board]] is created by the Alberta government as the provinces first organization partially responsible for energy resources. The organization later spawns the [[Petroleum and Natural Gas Conservation Board]], then the [[Energy and Utilities Board
column3: Energy Utilities Board]], and is then split into [[Energy Resources Conservation Board]] and [[Alberta Energy Regulator]].

column4: title=100 years of service and counting

column3: Alberta Natural Resources Act]] passed, transferring control of [[Natural resource
column4: natural resources]] and [[Crown land]] to Alberta.

British businessman}}: Alberta government levies its first royalty, at five percent, on oil and gas production.

column3: Shell]] opens exploration offices in Alberta.

British businessman}}: [[Leduc No. 1]] strikes oil starting Alberta's post-[[World War II]] oil boom.
Interprovincial Pipeline (currently [[Enbridge Line 1]]) constructed as the first large pipeline to carry Alberta oil.

column3: Pembina No. 1]] is drilled marking the first use of [[Hydraulic fracturing

British businessman}}: [[Trans Mountain Pipeline]] enters use as the first pipeline to carry Alberta oil to the [[Pacific Ocean
[[Rainbow Lake oil field]] discovered by [[Banff Oil Company]].

column3: 1973 Oil Crisis]] begins precipitated by Western involvement in the [[Yom Kippur War]] causes [[OPEC]] to embargo many Western countries, increasing the price and thus competitiveness of Alberta oil.

British businessman}}: [[Nova Chemicals]] opens the first [[ethylene]] plant in Alberta to be used in [[plastic]] production.
[[National Energy Program]] is announced by the [[32nd Canadian Parliament
column4: anger and resentment in the West]] and set to take effect on January 1, 1981.

British businessman}}: [[Western Accord]] takes effect, ending the National Energy Program.
[[Cenovus Energy]] pilots the first use of the [[Steam-assisted gravity drainage
column3: SAGD system]], technology developed by the Alberta Crown corp, the [[Alberta Oil Sands Technology and Research Authority]] at its Foster Creek location.

British businessman}}: [[Imperial Oil]] announces headquarters move from [[Toronto]] to Calgary.

column6: title=Imperial Oil cites proximity as reason for head office move

British businessman}}: Trans Mountain Pipeline announced to be bought by federal government after the pipelines expansion faced ongoing regulatory delays for five years.

<ref>[https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/liberals-trans-mountain-pipeline-kinder-morgan-1.4681911 \"Liberals to buy Trans Mountain pipeline for $4.5B to ensure expansion is built\"]. ''CBC News''. Retrieved May 30, 2018.</ref>

column3: Timeline of the 2020 Canadian pipeline and railway protests}}

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[2020 Canadian pipeline and railway protests]] being as members of the [[Mohawks of the Bay of Quinte First Nation]] blockade a [[Canadian National Railway]] rail line just north of [[Tyendinaga Mohawk Territory]].

British businessman}}: <ref>Spitters, John (February 7, 2020). [https://www.quintenews.com/2020/02/07/227816/ \"PHOTOS: Tyendinaga protesters stop train traffic\"]. ''Quinte News''. Retrieved February 10, 2020.</ref>

fix link and age at death,safe,Aivin G.,: [[File:Graph price of oil 1861 to 2020 WID data.png
[[Category:History of the petroleum industry in Canada]]","Below is a brief timeline covering the '''history of the petroleum industry [[Alberta]]''' and its predecessor states.

British businessman}}: [[Captain Swan]] reports finding \"gum or pitch\" in the region now known as the [[Athabasca oil sands
column3: Athabasca oil sand]]. The Captain's report is the first known to mention the oil sands.

British businessman}}: [[George Mercer Dawson]] files the first government report of the oil sands when surveying for the [[International Boundary Commission]].
The [[Rocky Mountain Development Company]] drills the first oil producing well, [[Lineham Discovery Well No. 1]], in [[Western Canada]] at Cameron Creek.

column4: title=How the West was Won: Alberta’s First Oil Well

British businessman}}: The ''[[Alberta Act]]'' creates Alberta as a province from the [[Northwest Territories
column3: North-West Territories]]. Resource rights are still held by the federal government.

British businessman}}: [[Dingman No. 1]] strikes oil starting a oil boom that subsides due to [[World War I]].

[[Public Utilities Board]] is created by the Alberta government as the provinces first organization partially responsible for energy resources. The organization later spawns the [[Petroleum and Natural Gas Conservation Board]], then the [[Energy and Utilities Board
column3: Energy Utilities Board]], and is then split into [[Energy Resources Conservation Board]] and [[Alberta Energy Regulator]].

column4: title=100 years of service and counting

column3: Alberta Natural Resources Act]] passed, transferring control of [[Natural resource
column4: natural resources]] and [[Crown land]] to Alberta.

British businessman}}: Alberta government levies its first royalty, at five percent, on oil and gas production.

column3: Shell]] opens exploration offices in Alberta.

British businessman}}: [[Leduc No. 1]] strikes oil starting Alberta's post-[[World War II]] oil boom.
Interprovincial Pipeline (currently [[Enbridge Line 1]]) constructed as the first large pipeline to carry Alberta oil.

column3: Pembina No. 1]] is drilled marking the first use of [[Hydraulic fracturing

British businessman}}: [[Trans Mountain Pipeline]] enters use as the first pipeline to carry Alberta oil to the [[Pacific Ocean
[[Rainbow Lake oil field]] discovered by [[Banff Oil Company]].

column3: 1973 Oil Crisis]] begins precipitated by Western involvement in the [[Yom Kippur War]] causes [[OPEC]] to embargo many Western countries, increasing the price and thus competitiveness of Alberta oil.

British businessman}}: [[Nova Chemicals]] opens the first [[ethylene]] plant in Alberta to be used in [[plastic]] production.
[[National Energy Program]] is announced by the [[32nd Canadian Parliament
column4: anger and resentment in the West]] and set to take effect on January 1, 1981.

British businessman}}: [[Western Accord]] takes effect, ending the National Energy Program.
[[Cenovus Energy]] pilots the first use of the [[Steam-assisted gravity drainage
column3: SAGD system]], technology developed by the Alberta Crown corp, the [[Alberta Oil Sands Technology and Research Authority]] at its Foster Creek location.

British businessman}}: [[Imperial Oil]] announces headquarters move from [[Toronto]] to Calgary.

column6: title=Imperial Oil cites proximity as reason for head office move

British businessman}}: Trans Mountain Pipeline announced to be bought by federal government after the pipelines expansion faced ongoing regulatory delays for five years.

<ref>[https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/liberals-trans-mountain-pipeline-kinder-morgan-1.4681911 \"Liberals to buy Trans Mountain pipeline for $4.5B to ensure expansion is built\"]. ''CBC News''. Retrieved May 30, 2018.</ref>
